member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Evaluator.Evaluator
member.summary: Allows you to evaluate mathematical expressions at runtime.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Evaluator.Evaluator.Expression
member.summary: Gets or sets the mathematical expression that you want to evaluate. This expression is case-insensitive. You can use x as the input variable, and you can send its value as a parameter when you call the Evaluate method. The expression can contain arithmitic operators like (+ - * / % Mod ^). You can also use the methods of the Math type. For example: Evaluator.Expression = "(2 + 3 * x) / Sin(GetRadians(x))" For simplicity, you can use Radians instead or GetRadians or even use Rad: Evaluator.Expression = "(2 + 3 * x) / Sin(Rad(x))" For more info about the math expression syntax, see the sVB docs reference book.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Evaluator.Evaluator.Evaluate(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Calculates the value of the mathematical expression with x substituted with the given value.
member.param: The value to substitute x with.
member.returns: The value of the mathematical expression at the given x.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Evaluator.Evaluator.LastErrors
member.summary: Returns a string that contains details about last errors that happened while parsing and evaluating the current expression.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array
member.summary: This object provides a way of storing more than one value for a given name. These values can be accessed by another index.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.EmptyArray
member.summary: Creates an empty array. You can also use x = {} to create an empty array.
member.returns: an empty array

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.AddItem(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds an item to the array.
member.param: the input array
the item you want to add after the last item in the array.
member.returns: a new array with the new item added. The input array will not be changed

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.AddNextItem(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds an item to the array. The input array will be changed directly, so this method is faster when you want to build a large array, but be careful because it will affect the reference array that the current array is copied from! sVB calls this method when you use the array intializer {}, so it is faster than adding individual items using the array indixer [].
member.param: The input array. The array must be intialized first, even with an empty array {}.
The item you want to add after the last item in the array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.Append(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds an item at the end of the array. The input array will be changed directly, so this method is faster when you want to build a large array, but be careful because it will affect the reference array that the current array is copied from! sVB calls this method when you use the array intializer {}, so it is faster than adding individual items using the array indixer [].
member.param: The input array. The array must be intialized first, even with an empty array {}.
The item you want to add after the last item in the array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.AddItems(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds many items to the array.
member.param: the input array
an array containing the items to add eact of them as a single item at the end of the array.
member.returns: a new array with the given items. The input array will not be changed

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.AddKeyValue(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds an item to the array, with the given key and value
member.param: the input array
the key of the item. If there is already an item with this key, it's value will be modified
the value of the item
member.returns: a new arry with the item added. the input array will not be changed

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.GetItemAt(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets the value of the array item that exists at the given numeric position.
member.param: The given array.
A number that represents the position of the item in the array, which not always be the same as its index (key). Note that position must be > 0.
member.returns: the item value if found, otherwise empty string "".

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.SetItemAt(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Sets the value of the array item that exists at the given numeric position. The input array will be changed directly, so this method is faster then the array indexer [] when dealing with a large array, but be careful because it will affect the reference array that the current array is copied from!
member.param: The given array.
A number that represents the position of the item in the array, which is not always the same as its index (key). Note that position must be > 0.
The item value.
member.returns: the item key if found at the given position, otherwise an empty string "".

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.GetKeyAt(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets the key of the array item that exists at the given numeric position.
member.param: The given array.
A number that represents the position of the item in the array, which not always be the same as its index (key). Note that position must be > 0.
member.returns: the item key if found, otherwise empty string "".

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.ContainsIndex(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets whether or not the array contains the specified index. This is very useful when deciding if the array's index was initialized by some value or not.
member.param: The array to check.
The index to check.
member.returns: True" or "False" depending on if the index was present in the specified array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Array.ContainsValue(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets whether or not the array contains the specified value. This is very useful when deciding if the array's value was stored in some index.
member.param: The array to check.
The value to check.
member.returns: "True" or "False" depending on if the value was present in the specified array.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File
member.summary: The File object provides methods to access, read and write information from and to a file on disk. Using this object, it is possible to save and open settings across multiple sessions of your program.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.LastError
member.summary: Gets or sets the last encountered file operation based error message. This property is useful for finding out when some method fails to execute.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.ReadContents(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens a file and reads the entire file's contents. This method will be fast for small files that are less than 1 MB in size, but will start to slow down and will be noticeable for files greater than 10MB.
member.param: The full path of the file to read, like c:\temp\settings.data.
member.returns: The entire contents of the file.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.WriteContents(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens a file and replaces its data with the given contents.
member.param: The full path of the file, like c:\temp\settings.data.
The contents to write into the specified file. You can send an array to write its elements to the file, each element in a line.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.WriteArray(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens a file and replaces its data with the given array.
member.param: The full path of the file, like c:\temp\settings.data.
The array to write its string representaion into the specified file.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.ReadLine(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and reads the contents at the specified line number. Don't use this method in a loop to read many lines from the same file, because it always starts reading from the first line of the file until it reaches the required line, which will have a very bad impact in loops. Instead, if the file size is less than 1 mega bytes, you can use the ReadLines method to read all the file lines then walk through it using the loop as you want.
member.param: The full path of the file to read from, like c:\temp\settings.data.
The line number of the text to be read.
member.returns: The text at the specified line of the specified file. You should check the File.LastError property to know if the empty string results from an empty line or from a wrong line number or none existing file.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.ReadLines(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and reads all its lines.
member.param: The full path of the file to read from, like c:\temp\settings.data.
member.returns: an array containing the lines of the specified file, or an empty string if the file is not found.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.ReadArray(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and reads its data as an array.
member.param: The full path of the file to read from, like c:\temp\settings.data.
member.returns: an array if the specified file content is a valid string representation of an array, or an empty string otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.WriteLine(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and writes the contents at the specified line number. This operation will overwrite any existing content at the specified line. Don't use this method to write many lines in the same file using a loop, as it will have a bad impact on performance, because it involves copying all file lines to a temp file to write the given content at the given line number, which will be repeated for every line you write using the loop! Instead, add all lines to an array and use the WriteLines method to write it at once.
member.param: The full path of the file to read from. An example of a full path will be c:\temp\settings.data.
The line number of the text to write.
The contents to write at the specified line of the specified file.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.WriteLines(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and writes the given lines starting from the specified line number. This operation will overwrite any existing content at the corresponding file lines. Don't use this method in a loop, as it will have a bad impact on performance, because it involves copying all file lines to a temp file to write the the given content at the given line number, which will be repeated for every line you write using the loop! Instead, add all lines to an array and write it for once.
member.param: The full path of the file. An example of a full path will be c:\temp\settings.data.
The line number to write the first item of the lines array at.
An array to write its items to the file, each item at a line, starting at the given line number.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.InsertLine(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and inserts the contents at the specified line number. This operation will not overwrite any existing content at the specified line. Don't use this method to write many lines in the same file using a loop, as it will have a bad impact on performance, because it involves copying all file lines to a temp file to insert the the given content at the given line number, which will be reoeated for every line you write using the loop! Instead, add all lines to one array and use the InsertLines method to insert it at once.
member.param: The full path of the file to read from, like c:\temp\settings.data.
The line number of the text to insert.
The contents to insert into the file.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.InsertLines(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and inserts the contents at the specified line number. This operation will not overwrite any existing content at the specified line. Don't use this method in a loop, as it will have a bad impact on performance, because it involves copying all file lines to a temp file to insert the the given content at the given line number, which will be reoeated for every line you write using the loop! Instead, add all lines to one array and send it to this method to insert all the lines in one call.
member.param: The full path of the file to read from, like c:\temp\settings.data.
The line number of the text to insert.
An arry to insert its items into the file, each in a new line.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.AppendLines(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and appends the contents to the end of the file then adds a new line.
member.param: The full path of the file to write to. An example of a full path will be c:\temp\settings.data.
The contents to append to the end of the file. You can send an array to append its elements to the file, each element in a line.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.AppendContents(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Opens the specified file and appends the contents to the end of the file.
member.param: The full path of the file to read from. An example of a full path will be c:\temp\settings.data.
The contents to append to the end of the file. If you send an array, its string representation wil be written as a single string, without adding any new lines betwee elements
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.CopyFile(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Copies the specified source file to the destination file path. If the destination points to a location that doesn't exist, the method will attempt to create it automatically. Existing files will be overwritten. It is always best to check if the destination file exists if you don't want to overwrite existing files.
member.param: The full path of the file that needs to be copied. An example of a full path will be c:\temp\settings.data.
The destination location or the file path.
member.returns: True if the operation was successful, or False otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.OpenFileDialog(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Shows the open file dialog, to allow the user to select a file from his PC file system.
member.param: An array containing extension filters, To allow you To specify the file types you want To open. Each extension filter itself Is an array, where: • the first Item descries the file type which ill be displayd in the dialog window in the file types dropdown list. • And the next items contain one Or more extension. • If you will open only one file type category Like images, you can send the extension filter directly as a one dimension array Like: {"Images", "bmp", "jpg", "gif"}. • otherise, send an array of extension filters Like {{"Text Files", ".txt"}, {"Images", "bmp", "jpg", "gif"}} • If you will open only a single extension, you can just use it as a single string like: "doc". • You can mix the above rules, such as { {"Text Files", ".txt"}, {"Images", "bmp", "jpg", "gif"}, "doc" } • If you want to show all files, use "" Or "*" as the extension, like: {"All Files", "*"}, Or just use "*".
member.returns: The file name that the user selected, or an empty string "" if he canceled the operation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.OpenFolderDialog(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Shows the open folder dialog, to allow the user to select a folder from his PC file system.
member.param: The folder path to be initialy selected when the dialog is shown. Use an empty string to let the dialog show the folder that the user copied to the clipboard or the last folder that was previously selected by the user.
member.returns: The folder name that the user selected, or an empty string "" if he canceled the operation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.File.SaveFileDialog(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Shows the save file dialog, to allow the user to enter the file name and choose a location in his PC file system to save the file to.
member.param: A suggested name to save the file with. The user can change this name in the dialog. You can use the full path of the file, to suggest the initial directory in the dialog, otherwise, the initial directory will be the last opened one.

Extension filters specify the file types you want to allow the dialog to view. Each filter consist of a description text and a list of file extensions. You can use a standard string filter, where a | is used to separate between the filter parts, and ; is used to separate between file extensions, like: "Text Files|*.txt|Images|*.bmp;*.jpg;*.gif|Doc|*.doc" Or you can use an array of extension filters, with each extension filter itself is an array, where: • the first Item descries the file type which ill be displayd in the dialog window in the file types dropdown list. • And the next items contain one Or more extension. • If you will open only one file type category Like images, you can send the extension filter directly as a one dimension array Like: {"Images", "bmp", "jpg", "gif"}. • otherise, send an array of extension filters Like {{"Text Files", ".txt"}, {"Images", "bmp", "jpg", "gif"}} • If you will open only a single extension, you can just use it as a single string like: "doc". • You can mix the above rules, such as { {"Text Files", ".txt"}, {"Images", "bmp", "jpg", "gif"}, "doc" } • If you want to show all files, use "" Or "*" as the extension, like: {"All Files", "*"}, Or just use "*".
member.returns: The file name that the user selected, or an empty string "" if he canceled the operation.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords
member.summary: Keywords object is a place holder for providing documentation for Small Basic Keywords

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.For
member.summary: The For statement allows you to execute a set of statements multiple times.
member.example:
The following example will print out numbers from 1 to 10
For i = 1 To 10 TextWindow.WriteLine(i) Next

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.EndFor
member.summary: Check the For statement for information about the EndFor keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Next
member.summary: Check the For statement for information about the Next keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.To
member.summary: Check the For statement for information about the To keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Step
member.summary: The Step keyword is used to specify an increment in the For loop.
member.example:
The following example will print out odd numbers from 1 to 10
For i = 1 to 10 Step 2 TextWindow.WriteLine(i) Next

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.If
member.summary: The If statement allows you to make decisions to do different things.
member.example:
The following example will print out either "Win" or "Lose" depending on the outcome of the flip.
If flip = "Tail" Then TextWindow.WriteLine("Win") Else TextWindow.WriteLine("Lose") EndIf

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Then
member.summary: Check the If statement for information about the Then keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Else
member.summary: Check the If statement for information about the Else keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.ElseIf
member.summary: The ElseIf keyword helps provide an alternate condition while making decisions using the If statement.
member.example:
In the following example, we will print out the right greeting based on the time of the day.
If Clock.Hour < 12 Then TextWindow.WriteLine("Good Morning") ElseIf Clock.Hour < 16 Then TextWindow.WriteLine("Good Afternoon") ElseIf Clock.Hour < 20 Then TextWindow.WriteLine("Good Evening") EndIf

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.EndIf
member.summary: Check the If statement for information about the EndIf keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Goto
member.summary: The Goto statement allows branching to a new location in the program.
member.example:
The following program will print consecutive numbers endlessly.
start: TextWindow.WriteLine(i) i = i + 1 Goto start

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Sub
member.summary: The Sub (Subroutine) statement allows you to do groups of things with a single call.
member.example:
The following example defines a subroutine that rings the bell and prints "Win".
Sub Win Sound.PlayBellRing() TextWindow.WriteLine("Win!") EndSub

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.EndSub
member.summary: Check the Sub statement for information about the EndSub keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.While
member.summary: The While statement allows you to repeat something until you achieve a desired result.
member.example:
The following code will print a set of random numbers until one that is greater than 100 is encountered.
While i < 100 i = Math.GetRandomNumber(150) TextWindow.WriteLine(i) Wend

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.EndWhile
member.summary: Check the While statement for information about the EndWhile keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Wend
member.summary: Check the While statement for information about the Wend keyword.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.And
member.summary: Does a logical computation and returns true if both inputs are true.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Keywords.Or
member.summary: Does a logical computation and returns true if either one of the inputs is true.

member.returns: The ceiling value of the given number.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Math.Floor(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)

member.returns: The floor value of the given number.

The default value is True, but you can set if to False to use degress instead. Note that this property will also affect how the Evaluator works.

member.returns: The cosine of the given angle.

member.param: The hexadecimal number whose decimal value is required. This argument can be omitted if you call this method as an extension method (with the name ToDeciaml) of a numeric or string variables, because hexa numbrs can be a pure digital numbers like 10 which is the hexa represntaion of 16 in the decimal system, or it can contain letters from A to F which makes it a string.
member.returns: The decimal value the hexa number if it is valid, or an empty string otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Sound.Load(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Loads an audio file, so you can call the Play method to play it later without suffering from any initial delay.
member.param: The path for the audio file. This could either be a local file (e.g.: c:\music\track1.mp3) or a file on the network (e.g.: http://contoso.com/track01.wma). You can load mp3, wav and wma files. Other file formats may or may not be valid depending on the audio codecs installed on the user's computer.
member.returns: If the audio file is loaded correctly, this method will return the file path, so you can send it to the Play, Pause and Stop methods, otherwise this method will return an empty string.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Sound.Play(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)

member.param: The path for the audio file. This could either be a local file (e.g.: c:\music\track1.mp3) or a file on the network (e.g.: http://contoso.com/track01.wma). ''' The file type could be an mp3 or wav or wma file. Other file formats may or may not play depending on the audio codecs installed on the user's computer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Sound.Resume(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Resumes playing the given audio from the position it was paused at. If the file hasn't not played yet, this operation will play it from start.
member.param: The path for the audio file. This could either be a local file (e.g.: c:\music\track1.mp3) or a file on the network (e.g.: http://contoso.com/track01.wma). The file type could be an mp3 or wav or wma file. Other file formats may or may not play depending on the audio codecs installed on the user's computer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Sound.PlayAndWait(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)

summary.para: Plays an audio file and waits until it is finished playing. This could be an mp3 or wav or wma file. Other file formats may or may not play depending on the audio codecs installed on the user's computer.
If the file was already paused, this operation will resume from the position where the playback was paused.

member.param: The path for the audio file. This could either be a local file (e.g.: c:\music\track1.mp3) or a file on the network (e.g.: http://contoso.com/track01.wma).

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle
member.summary: The Turtle provides Logo-like functionality to draw shapes by manipulating the properties of a pen and drawing primitives.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the turtle width. The default value is 16, and the minimum value is 4. Note that changeing the turtle width will also set its height to the same value.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets the turtle height. The default value is 16, and the minimum value is 4. Note that changeing the turtle height will also set its width to the same value.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Speed
member.summary: Specifies how fast the turtle should move. Valid values are 1 to 50. The default value is 5.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.UseAnimation
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the turtle moves and turns are animated. The default value is True, which is OK in most cases, and you can increase the Turtle.Speed up to 50 to make it faster. But you may need to set this property fo false while you are drawing curves, which require many turns and succissive short movements, which make the turtle too slow because of the animations overhead. Setting this property to False, will make the Move, MoveTo and Turn methods call the DirectMove, DirectMoveTo and DirectTurn Methods to avoid using animation, which will make thee turtle super fast. You can also call the three `Direct` methods manually even when this property is set to True, which allows you to mix animated and non-animated moves.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Angle
member.summary: Gets or sets the current angle of the turtle. While setting, this will turn the turtle instantly to the new angle.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.X
member.summary: Gets or sets the X location of the Turtle. While setting, this will move the turtle instantly to the new location.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Y
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y location of the Turtle. While setting, this will move the turtle instantly to the new location.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Show
member.summary: Shows the Turtle to enable interactions with it.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Hide
member.summary: Hides the Turtle and disables interactions with it.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.PenDown
member.summary: Sets the pen down to enable the turtle to draw as it moves.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.PenUp
member.summary: Lifts the pen up to stop drawing as the turtle moves.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.CreateFigure
member.summary: Uses the next turtle movements to create a closed figure, so that you can fill it by calling the FillFigure method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.FillFigure
member.summary: Closes the figure the Turtle created after calling the CreateFigure method, and filsl it with the GraphicsWindow.BrushColor. After calling this method, the figure Is completed, And you need To create a New figure If you want To fill a New area. If there Is no figure, calling this method will Do Nothing.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.Move(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Moves the turtle to a specified distance. If the pen is down, it will draw a line as it moves.
member.param: The distance to move the turtle.

member.summary: Moves the turtle to a specified distance directly without animation. If the pen is down, it will draw a line as it moves.

member.param: The angle in degrees to turn the turtle. It can be either positive or negative: If the angle is positive, the turtle turns to its right. If it is negative, the turtle turns to its left.

member.summary: Turns the turtle by the specified angle directly without any animation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Turtle.TurnLeft

member.summary: Searches the array for the given value, and returns its index position in the array.

an integer representing the array index to start searching at
set it to true if you want to do an case-insensitive search

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ArrayEx.GetItemAt(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets value of the array item that exists at the given numeric position.
member.param: A number that represents the position of the item in the array, which not always be the same as its index (key). Note that position must be > 0.
member.returns: the item value if found, otherwise empty string "".

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ArrayEx.SetItemAt(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Sets the value of the array item that exists at the given numeric position. The current array will be changed directly, so this method is faster then the array indexer [] when dealing with a large array, but be careful because it will affect the reference array that the current array is copied from!
member.param: A number that represents the position of the item in the array, which is not always the same as its index (key). Note that position must be > 0.
The item value.
member.returns: the item key if found at the given position, otherwise an empty string "".

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ArrayEx.GetKeyAt(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets the key of the array item that exists at the given numeric position.
member.param: A number that represents the position of the item in the array, which not always be the same as its index (key). Note that position must be > 0.
member.returns: the item key if found, otherwise empty string "".

member.summary: Searches the current array for the given value.
member.param: the item to search for
an integer representing the array index to start searching at
set it to true if you want to do an case-insensetive search
member.returns: the index or string key of the item if found, otherwise empty string

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ArrayEx.ToStr(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Converts the current array to a string.
member.returns: The string representation of the array. If the array is simple, its string can be of the form {1, 2, 3}. If the array contains keys, its string can be of the form {[1]=1, [2]=2, [Name]=Adam}.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ArrayEx.AddNextItem(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds an item to the array. The current array will be changed directly, so this method is faster when you want to build a large array, but be careful because it will affect the reference array that the current array is copied from! sVB calls this method when you use the array intializer {}, so it is faster than adding individual items using the array indixer [].
member.param: The item you want to add after the last item in the array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ArrayEx.Append(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds an item at the end of the array. The current array will be changed directly, so this method is faster when you want to build a large array, but be careful because it will affect the reference array that the current array is copied from! sVB calls this method when you use the array intializer {}, so it is faster than adding individual items using the array indixer [].
member.param: The item you want to add after the last item in the array.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Button
member.summary: Represents the Button control, that the user can click to perform the task that you provide in the OnClick event handler. You can use the form designer to add a button to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddButton method to create a new button and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.CheckBox
member.summary: Represents a CheckBox control, that the user can check or uncheck. Use the Checked property and OnCheck event to respond to the user choices. You can use the form designer to add a check box to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddCheckBox method to create a new check box and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.CheckBox.GetText(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that is displayed by the CheckBox

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.CheckBox.GetChecked(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: When True, the check box is checked. When False, the check box is unchecked. When empty string "", the check box is not checked nor unchecked (indeterminate state)

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.CheckBox.GetAllowThreeState(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Controls what happens when the user clicks the checkbox to cange its state: * When False(the defaust value): the checkbox state goes from checked to unchecked then back to checked and so on. * When True, the the checkbox state goes from checked to dimmed (indeterminate) to unchecked then back to checked and so on. Note that you can set the dimmed (indeterminate) state from code by setting the Checked property to an empty string "". This will always work regardless the value of AllowTriState, which has effect on the user interaction only.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to draw a line under the text.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to the text will be continue on the next line if it exceeds the width of the control.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Colors.None
member.summary: No color. Use this value when you don't want to draw the background color or the outline color. There is a difference between Colors.None and Colors.Transparent: ● The None color deletes the surface of the graphic, so, it doesn't respond to mouse and keyboard events, which are delivered to the underneath control. ● The Transparent color keeps the surfuce of the graphic but you can see through it, while it Is still responding to mouse And keyboard events.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ComboBox
member.summary: Represents a ComboBox control, which is composed of a textbox and a dropdown listbox. You can use the form designer to add a combo box to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddComboBox method to create a new combo box and add it to the form at runtime.

member.remarks: This property returns empty string if there is no item selected. But there can ba a selected item that displays an empty string! So, use the SelectedIndex property if you want to distinguish between the two cases. If you set the selectedItem to a value that doesn't existed in the list, no item will be selected.

member.summary: Gets the name of the control. Note that you can't change the control name at runtime. Use the designer to change the name.

member.summary: Gets the name of the control type, like TextBox, Label, and Button.

member.summary: An extra property to store any value you want that is related to the control. you can store multiple values as by putting them in an array or a dynamic object

member.summary: Gets or sets the x-pos of the left edge of control on its parent control.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetRight(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the x-pos of the right edge of control on its parent control.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetTop(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetBottom(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetWidth(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the control. If you want an auto-width to fit the control's content width, set this property to 0 or amy negative number. You can also limit the auto width by setting the MaxWidth property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetHeight(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the height of the control. If you want an auto-heigh to fit the control's content heigh, set this property to 0 or any negative number. You can also limit the auto height by setting the MaxHeigh property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetMaxWidth(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: The max width of the control. It is useful especially when you set the control's width to auto (Width = -1), to force the auto witdth not to exceed a max length. Setting this property to 0 or a negative value will reset it (no max width).

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetMaxHeight(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: The max height of the control. It is useful especially when you set the control's height to auto (Height = -1), to force the auto height not to exceed a max length. Setting this property to 0 or a negative value will reset it (no max height).

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetPadding(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding of the control, which is the internal space between the control edges and its content.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.FitContentWidth(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Changes the witdth of the control to fit its content width. This is a one time change, and will not make the control width auto-szied. If you want to make the width auto-sized, set the Width property to -1.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.FitContentHeight(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Changes the height of the control to fit its content height. This may be useful when you set WordWrap = True in labels and buttons. This is a one time change, and will not make the control height auto-szied. If you want to make the height auto-sized, set the Height property to -1.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.FitContentSize(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Changes the witdth and height of the control to fit its content size. This is a one time change, and will not make the control width and height auto-szied. If you want to make them auto-sized, set both Width and Height properties to -1.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetEnabled(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: When it is True, user can interact with the control. When it is False, the control is disabled, and user can't interact with it.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetVisible(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: When it is True, the control is shown at the form. When it is False, the control is hidden.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetRightToLeft(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the control content is displayed from right to left.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.GetMouseY(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: The mouse y-pos relative to the control. When mouse is over the control, this value lies between 0 and the control's height.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Control.Focus(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)

member.summary: Sets the resource dictionary of the control from the given file. The resource dictionary contains styles for the control and its child controls. This allows you to design advanced styles with other tools like VS.NET, save them to a file as a resource dictionary, then use this method to load it.
member.param: The xaml file that contains the resource dictionary.

member.param: The xaml file that contains the resource dictionary.
The key of style. The resource dictionary can contain many styles targetting the same control. This method will search for the style that have this key.

The culture name used to format the date, like "en-US" for English (United States) culture, "ar-EG" for Arabic (Egypt) culture, and "ar-SA" for Arabic (Saudi Arabia) culture. ''' Send an empty string "" to use the local culture of the user's system.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.DatePicker
member.summary: Represents a DatePicker control, that allows the user to enter a date or pick it from the drop down calendar. You can use the form designer to add a date picker to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddDatePicker method to create a new date picker and add it to the form at runtime.

member.summary: Gets the name of the control that raised the last event. It is useful when you use one sub to handle many events, to get info about the contol that fired the event.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Event.Handled
member.summary: If you set this property to true inside an event handler sub, the event will be considered handled and will not be processed by windows anymore. For example, if you want to cancel writrting a key to the textbox, use `Event.Handled = True` inside the OnKeyDown event handler.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Form
member.summary: Represents the Form control, which is the window that the user interacts with. It is easier use the form designer to add new forms and save it to a XAML file. It is also possible to crate forms at run time, by calling the Forms.AddForm method to create a new form, or the Forms.LoadForm method to load a form from the XAML file that contains its design, then call the Form.Show method to display the form.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Form.RunTests(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Runs the test functions written in the current form, and shows the test results in the TxtTest textbox. If the form doesn't contain a textbox with this name, it will be added at run time to show the results. The test function must follow these rules: 1. Its name must start with `Test_`, like `Test_FindNames`. 2. It must be a function not a sub, and it can't have any parameters. 3. The function return value should be a string containing the test result like "passed" or "failed". See the tests written in the "UnitTest Sample" project in the samples folder.
member.returns: the number of tests that have been run.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Form.RunGlobalTests(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Runs the test functions written in the global.sb file, and shows the test results in the TxtTest textbox on the current form. If the form doesn't contain a textbox with this name, it will be added at run time to show the results. The test function must follow these rules: 1. Its name must start with `Test_`, like `Test_FindNames`. 2. It must be a function not a sub, and it can't have any parameters. 3. The function return value should be a string containing the test result like "passed" or "failed". See the tests written in the "UnitTest Sample" project in the samples folder.
member.returns: the number of tests that have been run.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Form.Close(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Closes the form. This will clear any data displayed by its controls, as in fact the form will be totally disposed. You can't call the Form.Show method to show the form after it is closed, unless you re-created a new instance of it first. If you want to keep the form alive but just hide it, you can just set its Visible property to False to hide it, so you can still be able to show it. Note that closing the main form of the project will close the whole application. You can choose the main form by just open any form of the project in sVB and press F5 to run the project, so that form will be the first form displayed when the application starts up.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.GeometricPath
member.summary: Allows you to combine shapes into one path, and create new geometric figures from line and arc segments, so you can create new complex custom shapes. You can add the geometric path to the shapes collection by calling the Shapes.AddGeometricPath() method, then you can apply any rotation or animation on it as you do with any other normal shape. You can also add the the geometric path to any label on any form by calling the Label.AddGeometricPath method, so you can move, rotate or animate it using the label methods.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.GeometricPath.CreatePath
member.summary: creates a new geometric path to add geometric shapes to it, so you can compose complex shapes.

member.summary: Adds a new figure to the geometric path that starts at the given point
member.param: The x co-ordinate of the start point of the figure
The y co-ordinate of the start point of the figure
When True, a line segment is automatically drown between the last point and the start point of the figure to make it a closed shape. Use Fals if you want to draw an open figure like a curve.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.GeometricPath.AddLineSegment(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive,Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Adds a line segment to the current figure in the geometric path, starting from the last point in the figure to the given point.
member.param: The x co-ordinate of the end point of the line segment.
The y co-ordinate of the end point of the line segment.
Use True to draw the segment with the pen color, or False to hide the segment outline.

member.summary: Adds an arc segment to the current figure in the geometric path, starting from the last point in the figure to the given point. This arc is a part of the ellipse that has the given radius and passes through these tow points.
member.param: The x co-ordinate of the end point of the arc segment.
The y co-ordinate of the end point of the arc segment.
The horizontal radius of the arc
The vertical radius of the arc
The x-axis rotation of the ellipse
Use True if the arc should be greater than 180 degrees, or False otherwise
Use True to draw the arc in a positive angle direction, or False otherwise
Use True to draw the segment with the pen color, or False to hide the segment outline.

member.summary: Adds a cubic Bezier curve segment to the current figure in the geometric path, starting from the last point in the figure, passing through the two given control points, and ending at the given end point.
member.param: The x co-ordinate of the first control point.
The y co-ordinate of the first control point.
The x co-ordinate of the second control point.
The y co-ordinate of the second control point.
The x co-ordinate of the end point.
The y co-ordinate of the end point.
Use True to draw the segment with the pen color, or False to hide the segment outline.

member.summary: Adds a cubic quadratic Bezier curve segment to the current figure in the geometric path, starting from the last point in the figure, passing through the given control point and ending at the given end point.
member.param: The x co-ordinate of the control point.
The y co-ordinate of the control point.
The x co-ordinate of the end point.
The y co-ordinate of the end point.
Use True to draw the segment with the pen color, or False to hide the segment outline.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Label.GetLabel(System.String)
member.summary: Represents a Label control, that shows a text, a hyper link, an image or a graphic to the user. Use the Text property to set the text displayed by the label. You can also use the Append methods to add formatted text to the label. Use the AppendLink method to add a Hyper link to the label. Use the Image property to load an image from a file and display it in the label. Use the Add methods to add geometric shapes to the label. You can use the form designer to add a label to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddLabel method to create a new label and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Label.GetText(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that is displayed on the label

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Label.GetImage(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the path of the image that is displayed on the label
Adds the given text at the end of the current label with the given formats.
member.param: The text to add to the label
The name of the font to apply on the text. Send an empty string to use the current label font
The font size of the text. Send 0 to use the current label font size
True to use a bold font, False otherwise. Send an empty string to use the current label FontBold value.
True to use an italic font, False otherwise. Send an empty string to use the current label FontItalic value.
True to draw aline under the text, False otherwise. Send an empty string to use the current label Underlined value.
The color of the text. Send Colors.None to use the current label foreColor.
The background color of the text. Send Colors.None to use the current label backColor.
The address to navigate to. Send empty string to view a normal text, otherwise the formated text will be viewed as a hyper link that opens the given url.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.MenuItem
member.summary: Represents the MenuItem control, which shows a menuItem on the main menu bar or on the dropdown list of a parent manuItem. The user can click the menu item to perform the task you programmed in the OnClick event handler. You can also set the Checkable property to True to allow the user to check or uncheck the menu item, hence you can use the Checked property and the OnCheck event to respond the user choices. The form designer doesn't supoport adding menu items at design time, but you can use the MainMenu.AddItem method to add an item to the main menu, or use the MenuItem.AddItem to add an item to a pearent menu item. You can also use the MenuItem.AddSeparator to add a separator line to the menu item.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ProgressBar
member.summary: Represents the ProgressBar control, that indicates how much of the task has done. Use the Minimum and Maximun properties to set the progress range, and use the Value property to set the current progress. You can use the form designer to add a progress bar to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddProgressBar method to create a new progress bar and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ProgressBar.GetValue(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the progress value in current ProgressBar

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ProgressBar.GetMinimum(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the progress minimum value in current ProgressBar. The default value is 0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ProgressBar.GetMaximum(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the progress maximum value in current ProgressBar. The default value is 100. If you set the max value to 0, this will mean you don't know when the progress will end (indeterminate), so, it will show an infinitly moving marquee.

members.member: Represents a RadioButton control, that the user can check or uncheck. You can use the Checked property and OnCheck event to respond to the user choices. You can use the form designer to add a radio button to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddRadioButton method to create a new radio button and add it to the form at runtime. Radio buttons work togethor as a group, where each group can contain only one checked radio button. By default, all radio buttons you add to the form will be grouped together, but if you want to create more than one goup, you can group some radio buttons together by setting the GroupNmae property in each of them to the same group name. You can also use the form designer to group radiobuttons by selecting them, right-clicking one of the selected radio buttons, and clicking the Group command from the context menu.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.RadioButton.GetText(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that is displayed by the RadioButton

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.RadioButton.GetGroupName(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the radio buttons group. Radio buttons that belong to the same group can have only one seleected button at a time, so, if the user checks one button, the previously checked button will be unchecked.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.RadioButton.GetChecked(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: When True, the radio button is checked. When False, the radio button is unchecked. When empty string "", the radio button is not checked nor unchecked (indeterminate state)

member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to draw a line under the text.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to the text will be continue on the next line if it exceeds the width of the control.

member.name: E:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.RadioButton.OnCheck
member.summary: Fired when the checked state is changed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ScrollBar
member.summary: Represents the ScrollBar control, that allows the user to scroll a value within a range. Use the Minimum and Maximun properties to set the scroll range, use the Value property to set the current scroll position, and use the OnScroll event to take action when the scroll position changes. You can use the form designer to add a scroll bar to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddScrollBar method to create a new scroll bar and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ScrollBar.GetMaximum(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum value of the current ScrollBar. The default value is 100.

member.name: E:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ScrollBar.OnScroll

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Slider
member.summary: Represents the Slider control, that allows the user to choose a value within a range. Use the Minimum and Maximun properties to set the slider range, use the Value property to set the current slide position, and use the OnSlide event to take action when the slider value changes. You can use the form designer to add a slider to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddSlider method to create a new slider and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Slider.GetSnapToTick(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not the thumb movment snaps to tick marquees when the user slides it. Set this property to True and set the TickFrequency property to a proper value to show marquees on the slider, and force the user to slide only to marquees positions. The default value is False, which gives the user freedom to slide to positions between tha marquees.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.TextBox
member.summary: Represents the TextBox control, which allows the user to input text. Use the Text property to read the text the user wrote. Use the OnTextInput event to intercept the text before it is written to the textbox. Use the OnTextChanged to take action after the text of the textbox changes. You can use the form designer to add a textbox to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddTextBox method to create a new textbox and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Thread.InitializationDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets the time in milliseconds that the main thread will be paused for, to allow the new thread to start and read the global variables. The default value is 10, but you can increase it if the the thread needs to read many global variables. Use 0 if you don't need any delay.

member.name: E:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.Thread.SubToRun
member.summary: This is not actually an event, but when you set its handler, it will be called immediately in a new thread to allow you to use execute a task in parallel to your normal code. You can set this handler more than one time to create many threads, but take care not to create too many threads (at most 100 threads and the lesser the better) because that can make your system hang or block some of these threads. Note also that you can't pass arguments to the handler, so you will need to use global variables. Warning: Threads will not be created in debug mode to allow you to trace the code. In this case your program may be slower and some of its logic may not function correctly.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.WinTimer
member.summary: Represents the WinTimer control, which provides an easy way for doing something repeatedly with a constant interval between. Use the Interval property to set the time between ticks, and write the code you want to be executed in the OnTick event handler. This object differs that the Timer object, as you can add many win timers as you want to each form in the project, while there is only a single Timer object that was suitable to SB code files. You can't use the form designer to add Win timers to thee form, but you can use the Form.AddTimer method to add a new timer to the form.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.WinTimer.GetInterval(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets the interval (in milliseconds) specifying how often the timer should raise the Tick event. Setting this property will start or resume the timer and tick events will be raised.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.WinTimer.Pause(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Pauses the timer. Tick events will not be raised.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.WinTimer.GetIsEnabled(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Returns false if the timer is paused, or True otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.WinTimer.Resume(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Resumes the timer from a paused state. Tick events will now be raised.

member.name: E:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.WinTimer.OnTick
member.summary: Fired when user releases the left mouse-button

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.WinTimer.RemoveOnTickHandler(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Removes the OnTick hamdler of the current timer. Ulternatively, you can set the OnTick event to Nothing to remove its handler: myTimer.OnTick = Nothing

member.name: T:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ToggleButton
member.summary: Represents a ToggleButton control, that the user can check or uncheck. The toggle button looks like a bormal button, but when the user clicks it it stays down (checked), and when he clicks it again, the button returns to its normal state (unchecked) Use the Checked property and OnCheck event to respond to the user choices. You can use the form designer to add a toggle button to the form by dragging it from the toolbox. It is also possible to use the Form.AddToggleButton method to create a new toggle button and add it to the form at runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ToggleButton.GetIsFlat(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to show the toggleButton with a flat style.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.WinForms.ToggleButton.GetChecked(Microsoft.SmallVisualBasic.Library.Primitive)
member.summary: When True, the toggle button is checked. When False, the toggle button is unchecked. When empty string "", the toggle button is not checked nor unchecked (indeterminate state)

member.summary: Fired when the checked state is changed.
